title: Format powers of ten
text: R Markdown (Allaire et al. 2022) Quarto Markdown (Allaire 2022), use inline equation markup delimited $...$ create math expression output document. example, markup Avogadro’s number given , yields \(N_A = 6.0221 \times 10^{23}\) document. program markup, however, enclose markup character string, , requires backward slash \ “escaped”, hence product symbol denoted \\times. form output produced format_power().

title: Format powers of ten
text: Given number, numerical vector, numerical column data frame, format_power() converts numbers character strings form, coefficient n exponent. user can specify number significant digits, scientific engineering format, range decimal notation enforced. Arguments. x   Numerical vector formatted. Can scalar, vector, column data frame. digits   Positive nonzero integer specify number significant digits. Default 3. format   Possible values “engr” (engineering notation) “sci” (scientific notation). Default “engr”. limits   Numeric vector length two, default c(0.1, 1000), specifying range \(p\leq{}<q\) number \(\) printed without power--ten notation. writing script follow along, use packages vignette: Equivalent usage.   first two arguments named argument order maintained.
code: "$a\\times{10}^{n}$" library("formatdown") library("data.table") # Numerical value avogadro <- 6.0221E+23  # Arguments named (x <- format_power(x = avogadro, digits = 3)) #> [1] "$602\\times{10}^{21}$"  # Arguments unnamed y <- format_power(avogadro, 3)  # Implicit use of default argument z <- format_power(avogadro)  # Demonstrate equivalence all.equal(x, y) #> [1] TRUE all.equal(x, z) #> [1] TRUE

title: Format powers of ten
text: Scalar.   Use inline R code. , Rmd qmd document, rendered \(602\times{10}^{21}\). Vector.   rendered \(1.22\times{10}^{-6}\), \(23.3\times{10}^{-6}\), \(344\times{10}^{-6}\), etc. Significant digits.   Argument named. rendered \(1.22\times{10}^{-6}\) \(1.222\times{10}^{-6}\) Format.   Argument, included, must named. rendered \(3.44\times{10}^{-4}\) \(344\times{10}^{-6}\) Limits.   Argument, included, must named. rendered \(0.633\) \(633\times{10}^{-3}\) compare effects across many orders magnitude, treat example vector convert one-column data frame display, rendered using using knitr::kable(), Data frame.   Using density, data frame included formatdown contains columns class Date, character, factor, numeric, integer. rendered un-formatted Treating column vector, rendered \(101.1\times{10}^{3}\), \(101.0\times{10}^{3}\), \(101.1\times{10}^{3}\), \(101.0\times{10}^{3}\), \(101.1\times{10}^{3}\). Treating column within data frame, rendered Using lapply() select treat multiple columns data frame, rendered Repeat, retain columns, rendered different columns reported different significant digits, treat columns separately. rendered Non-numeric input.   Applying function non-numeric objects produces errors. example, “Date” class. Error “character” class, Error “factor” class,
code: format_power(avogadro) #> [1] "$602\\times{10}^{21}$" x <- c(   1.2222e-6, 2.3333e-5, 3.4444e-4, 4.1111e-3, 5.2222e-2, 6.3333e-1,   7.4444e+0, 8.1111e+1, 9.2222e+2, 1.3333e+3, 2.4444e+4, 3.1111e+5, 4.2222e+6 ) format_power(x) #>  [1] "$1.22\\times{10}^{-6}$" "$23.3\\times{10}^{-6}$" "$344\\times{10}^{-6}$"  #>  [4] "$4.11\\times{10}^{-3}$" "$52.2\\times{10}^{-3}$" "$0.633$"                #>  [7] "$7.44$"                 "$81.1$"                 "$922$"                  #> [10] "$1.33\\times{10}^{3}$"  "$24.4\\times{10}^{3}$"  "$311\\times{10}^{3}$"   #> [13] "$4.22\\times{10}^{6}$" format_power(x[1], 3) #> [1] "$1.22\\times{10}^{-6}$" format_power(x[1], 4) #> [1] "$1.222\\times{10}^{-6}$" format_power(x[3], format = "sci") #> [1] "$3.44\\times{10}^{-4}$" format_power(x[3], format = "engr") #> [1] "$344\\times{10}^{-6}$" format_power(x[6], limits = c(0.1, 1000)) #> [1] "$0.633$" format_power(x[6], limits = c(1, 1000)) #> [1] "$633\\times{10}^{-3}$" # Format using defaults and convert to a data frame DT <- data.table(   scientific = format_power(x, format = "sci"),   engineering = format_power(x) ) knitr::kable(DT, align = "rr") density #>          date  trial humidity    T_K   p_Pa     R  density #>        <Date> <char>   <fctr>  <num>  <num> <int>    <num> #> 1: 2018-06-12      a      low 294.05 101100   287 1.197976 #> 2: 2018-06-13      b     high 294.15 101000   287 1.196384 #> 3: 2018-06-14      c   medium 294.65 101100   287 1.195536 #> 4: 2018-06-15      d      low 293.35 101000   287 1.199647 #> 5: 2018-06-16      e     high 293.85 101100   287 1.198791 # Copy to avoid "by reference" changes to density DT <- copy(density)  # Format as a vector format_power(DT$p_Pa, digits = 4) #> [1] "$101.1\\times{10}^{3}$" "$101.0\\times{10}^{3}$" "$101.1\\times{10}^{3}$" #> [4] "$101.0\\times{10}^{3}$" "$101.1\\times{10}^{3}$" # Copy to avoid "by reference" changes to density DT <- copy(density)  # Format one column, retain all columns DT$p_Pa <- format_power(DT$p_Pa, digits = 4) DT[] #>          date  trial humidity    T_K                   p_Pa     R  density #>        <Date> <char>   <fctr>  <num>                 <char> <int>    <num> #> 1: 2018-06-12      a      low 294.05 $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$   287 1.197976 #> 2: 2018-06-13      b     high 294.15 $101.0\\times{10}^{3}$   287 1.196384 #> 3: 2018-06-14      c   medium 294.65 $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$   287 1.195536 #> 4: 2018-06-15      d      low 293.35 $101.0\\times{10}^{3}$   287 1.199647 #> 5: 2018-06-16      e     high 293.85 $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$   287 1.198791 # Copy to avoid "by reference" changes to density DT <- copy(density)  # Identify columns to format cols_we_want <- c("T_K", "p_Pa", "density")  # Select and format. DT <- DT[, lapply(.SD, function(x) format_power(x, 4)), .SDcols = cols_we_want] DT[] #>        T_K                   p_Pa density #>     <char>                 <char>  <char> #> 1: $294.1$ $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$ $1.198$ #> 2: $294.1$ $101.0\\times{10}^{3}$ $1.196$ #> 3: $294.6$ $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$ $1.196$ #> 4: $293.4$ $101.0\\times{10}^{3}$ $1.200$ #> 5: $293.9$ $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$ $1.199$ # Copy to avoid "by reference" changes to density DT <- copy(density)  # Identify columns to format cols_we_want <- c("T_K", "p_Pa", "density")  # Format selected columns, retain all columns DT <- DT[, (cols_we_want) := lapply(.SD, function(x) format_power(x, 4)), .SDcols = cols_we_want] DT[] #>          date  trial humidity     T_K                   p_Pa     R density #>        <Date> <char>   <fctr>  <char>                 <char> <int>  <char> #> 1: 2018-06-12      a      low $294.1$ $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.198$ #> 2: 2018-06-13      b     high $294.1$ $101.0\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.196$ #> 3: 2018-06-14      c   medium $294.6$ $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.196$ #> 4: 2018-06-15      d      low $293.4$ $101.0\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.200$ #> 5: 2018-06-16      e     high $293.9$ $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.199$ # Copy to avoid "by reference" changes to density DT <- copy(density)  # Format selected columns, retain all columns with signif digits = 5 cols_we_want <- c("T_K", "density") DT <- DT[, (cols_we_want) := lapply(.SD, function(x) format_power(x, 5)), .SDcols = cols_we_want]  # Individually format one column with signif digits = 4 DT$p_Pa <- format_power(DT$p_Pa, 4) DT[] #>          date  trial humidity      T_K                   p_Pa     R  density #>        <Date> <char>   <fctr>   <char>                 <char> <int>   <char> #> 1: 2018-06-12      a      low $294.05$ $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.1980$ #> 2: 2018-06-13      b     high $294.15$ $101.0\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.1964$ #> 3: 2018-06-14      c   medium $294.65$ $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.1955$ #> 4: 2018-06-15      d      low $293.35$ $101.0\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.1996$ #> 5: 2018-06-16      e     high $293.85$ $101.1\\times{10}^{3}$   287 $1.1988$ x <- density$date format_power(x) #> Error in format_power(x): Assertion on 'class(x)' failed: Must be disjunct from {'Date','POSIXct','POSIXt'}, but has elements {'Date'}. x <- density$trial format_power(x) #> Error in format_power(x): Assertion on 'x' failed. Must be of class 'numeric', not 'character'. x <- density$humidity format_power(x) #> Error in format_power(x): Assertion on 'x' failed. Must be of class 'numeric', not 'factor'.
